bibl.title: Program from the University of Maryland Academic Day, November 11, 1908

div1.p: Welch is listed as having given a speech honoring Carroll. A bronze tablet memorializing Carroll was also unveiled.

div1.head: Program from the University of Maryland Academic Day, November 11, 1908
div1.p:
Being the 119th Anniversary of the Opening of St. John's College
Annapolis, Maryland

Order of Ceremonies at
Westminster Presbyterian Church
Fayette and Greene Streets
at 10.30 a. m. precisely

I. ENTRANCE OF THE ACADEMIC PROCESSION.
a. Students of the Department of Arts and Sciences, St. John's College.
b. Students of the Department of Medicine, Freshmen, Sophomores,
Juniors and Seniors.
c. Students of the Department of Law.
d. Students of the Department of Pharmacology.
e. Students of the Department of Dentistry.
f. The Chancellor, the Provost and the Regents of the University of
Maryland, Faculties and Adjunct Faculties.
g. Orators and Guests of the University of Maryland.
h. Alumni of the University of Maryland.
Music, Triumphal March of Entry, from “Rienzi”...........Wagner
Grand Organ.

2. INVOCATION--Rev. Thomas Grier Koontz.
Quartette, the 133rd Psalm.........................Horatio Parker
“Behold how good and pleasant it is for brethren to dwell together in unity.”
(The audience will please remain standing during the singing of the
Psalm.)

5. ADDRESS BY PROF. WILLIAM H. WELCH, M. D., LL. D.,
etc., on Major James Carroll, M. D., University of Maryland,
1891, and LL. D. 1907, coincident with the unveiling of a bronze
memorial tablet at the venerable Medical Building in honor of
Major Carroll.

7. ADDRESS BY CHARLES WILLIS NEEDHAM, LL. D., PRESI-
DENT OF GEORGE WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY, WASH-
INGTON, D. C.--“Efficient Men the Aim of University Training.”

11. EXIT OF THE CHANCELLOR, REGENTS, ORATORS, GUESTS
AND VARIOUS FACULTIES AND ADJUNCT FACULTIES
AND ALUMNI.
(The Student Body will remain standing during the passing out of
this body from the Church.)

THE MARSHALS--
Arthur S. Shipley, B. A., M. D., Chief Marshal.
H. W. Brent, M. D., Aid, and class marshals from all departments.

THE QUARTETTE is under the direction of B. Merrill Hopkinson, A.
M. and M. D., and consists of:
Mr. Frederick H. Weber, First Tenor.
Mr. H. Rea Fitch, Second Tenor.
B. Merrill Hopkinson, A. M., M. D., First Bass.
Mr. Harry M. Smith, Second Bass.
The Organist is Professor Robert Leroy Haslup, of the Brown
Memorial Presbyterian Church.
The Students of the various departments will assemble at 10 A. M.,
as follows:
Students of the Department of Arts and Sciences--St. John's College,
in the Lobby, Entrance Hall, Waiting Room of the Medical
Building.
The Freshmen and Sophomores of the Department of Medicine in
the Chemical Lecture Hall.
The Seniors and Juniors of the Department of Medicine in the Ana-
tomical Lecture Hall.
The Students of the Department of Law in the Hall of the Law
School.
The Students of the Department of Dentistry in the lower Hall and
Basement Laboratories of the Dental Building.
The Students of the Department of Pharmacy on the first floor of
the Pharmaceutical Building.
The Chancellor, Regents of the University of Maryland, Governors
of St. John's College, Faculties and Adjunct Faculties, Guests and
Orators of the University and the Alumni will assemble in Davidge
Hall, southeast corner of Greene and Lombard streets, in ACA-
DEMIC COSTUME, and proceed thence north on the east side of
Greene street to Westminster Presbyterian Church. In case of
rain this body will meet in the Lecture Room of the Westminster
Presbyterian Church.
The Student Body and the various Faculties will return to the Uni-
versity Building in the above order.
